title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, 22 june [1870]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 22 June [1870]
text: 1870June 22 Walter deari received your letter yesterday was glad to hear you was as well in regard to your lame thumb as you are i feel quite smart to day and yesterday it is much cooler the hot days does seem to take me down it has been some pretty hot days here but is quite comfortable to day) i had a letter from han last week she seems pretty well wants me to come there very much indeed i wrote to her that i didentdidn't know how to undertake the journeeyjourney in my condition being at times so very lame i dontdon't think i could go any how if i wasentwasn't lame i have got a dress and a few things to send her but i cantcan't go there this summer i suppose Charley heydeHeyde wrote he had paid all for his house if he was a decent man they might live quite comfortable but that will never be davisDavis was here yesterday he is employed at lowelLowell as cheifchief engineer he is not going to st louisSt. Louis till septemberSeptember and then he will stop here again he says he has many little petty annoyances so he thought he would come to new yorkNew York for a few days i told him i beleivedbelieved there was always something in every department some one sort and some another but there must be a something i expect he feels any little thing more not having Jeff to condole with him he is quite nerviousnervous and irritable at times he looks firsfirst rate georgeGeorge is away wontwon't come i dontdon't think till about the 4th so waltWalt you are going to have quite a great change in your department for better or for worser i suppose time will tell i see awfullawful things said about putting in Ackerman the ex rebel as he is called) i haventhaven't heard from st louisSt. Louis in a long time your letters is mostly all the corresspondencecorrespondence i have) no more this timegood bie walterWalter dearL W Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 22 June [1870]
